weekly_overview:
Based on the available trading data, this week saw significant congressional financial activity led by several high-volume traders. Representative Jefferson Shreve (R-Indiana) conducted the most trades with 42 transactions valued between $20.9 million and $52.6 million, while Representative Michael McCaul (R-Texas) executed 100 trades worth $8.8 million to $37.4 million. Representative Ro Khanna (D-California) led in transaction frequency with 182 trades, though at lower individual values totaling $767,000 to $3.9 million.

The top 10 most active congressional traders this week represented a mix of both parties, with Republican members dominating the higher-value transactions. Notable activity included trades by former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-California) with one transaction valued between $500,000-$1 million, and Senator Tommy Tuberville (R-Alabama) with 17 trades worth $348,000 to $1 million. The trading activity spans various portfolio sizes and frequencies, reflecting diverse investment strategies among congressional members.
top_movers:
Based on the congressional trading data, here are the most notable activities:

• **Shreve leads in trading volume and frequency**: Jefferson Shreve conducted the most transactions (42 total) with the highest portfolio value range of $20.9M - $52.6M, significantly outpacing other members in both trade count and dollar amounts.

• **McCaul shows high trading activity**: Michael T. McCaul executed 96 total transactions (21 purchases, 75 sales) with a portfolio value of $8.8M - $37.4M, representing the second-highest level of trading activity by transaction count.

• **Sale-heavy trading patterns**: Most members showed significantly more sales than purchases, with McCaul conducting 75 sales versus 21 purchases, and Shreve executing 27 sales versus 15 purchases.
industry_highlights: Based on the trading data, congressional members show a heavy concentration in traditional banking sector investments, with 116 banking trades representing nearly 90% of all financial sector activity tracked. The relatively modest 15 crypto trades suggest that while lawmakers are beginning to explore digital assets, their investment focus remains firmly anchored in established banking institutions.
